history.origin: The Nso' people migrated from Tikari in the Adamawa Region of Cameroon when there was a bloody succession after the death of Chief Tinki in 1387. The enthronement of Mveing as successor of Tinki sent all rivals to the throne away from Kimi. Ngonnso', the founder of the Nso' dynasty, left Kimi with a few followers together with her brothers Nchare Yen and Mbombam and their respective followers.
history.naming: The tribe got its name from Ngonnso', and is one of the largest tribes of Cameroon.

jujus.description: Masked spirits that are an important part of Nso culture (the word can also refer to some type of magic).

mfu.meetings: Gathers every eighth day (the traditional week)
mfu.purpose: Place where men in the village can come to hear the latest news and where the village leaders can disseminate information or organize village work
mfu.decorations: Most Mfu houses are richly decorated with carved posts, both inside and outside
mfu.requirements: To enter the Mfu house, one must wear a hat and a cutlass, and one must bring a drinking cup to partake in the drinking of 'Melu' (raffia palm wine)

agriculture.description: The Nso are primarily an agricultural society

gender_roles.women: Responsible for the cultivation and harvesting of crops

culture.social_structure: Organized around lineage groups, each led by a Fai

festivals.name: Ngam Ngonso Festival
festivals.description: Cultural week festival bringing together various aspects of Nso tradition and culture

language.name: Lamnso
language.classification: Grassfields Bantu language, specifically belonging to the East Ring Group of Narrow Grassfield languages
language.development: Began to be written down in the 1940s by Nso schoolteachers to teach in primary schools

legends.origin: The Nso people trace their origins to a migration from Tikar in the Adamawa region, led by Princess Ngonnso, following a succession dispute after the death of Chief Tinki in 1387.

key_events.name: The Succession Dispute
key_events.description: The death of Chief Tinki in 1387 led to a conflict over the throne, with Nchare Yen being passed over for his half-brother Mveing.

key_events.name: The Exodus
key_events.description: Nchare Yen, along with his brother Mbombam and their sister Ngonnso, decided to leave Tikar.

key_events.name: Ngonnso's Leadership
key_events.description: Ngonnso, initially intending to follow her brothers, ultimately established her own settlement due to a separation from them.

traditional_meals.name: Kati-Kati
traditional_meals.description: Spiced chicken that is first roasted, then cooked with palm oil, tomatoes, and spices

traditional_meals.name: Njama-Njama
traditional_meals.description: Vegetable stew, often made with leafy greens, steamed and simmered in palm oil with tomatoes and seasonings

traditional_meals.name: Fufu Corn
traditional_meals.description: A dough made from corn flour, boiled and stirred until it becomes a stiff consistency

headwear.name: Tan Gham
headwear.description: General-use cap signifying maturity when worn
headwear.special_variations: Adorned with cowries for the Fon (King) and high-ranking notables

headwear.name: Tan Lav
headwear.description: Not restricted to any particular group
headwear.military_variation: May affix a red feather for military titleholders

other_attire: Glass bead necklaces and fancy walking sticks for Fais

history.origin: Nkambe is a city in the Northwest Region of Cameroon. The Wimbum people probably arrived in this area between the 1700s and the mid-1800s.
history.migrations: Arrived in three waves: Warr, Wiya, and Tang clans

religious_beliefs.description: A blend of traditional beliefs and Christianity

economic_activities.commerce: Both within the region and in external trade

culture.social_structure: Organized into various fondoms (chiefdoms), each with its own Fon (chief)

traditional_meals.name: Fufu and Eru
traditional_meals.description: Fufu made from cassava with Eru soup made with leafy vegetables

traditional_meals.name: Kati Kati with Fufu Corn
traditional_meals.description: Grilled chicken with fufu made from corn

traditional_dress.description: Heavily embroidered, colorful outfit with intricate patterns

history.origin: Trace back to Tikar migrants who moved from the Adamawa Plateau. The kingdom was founded in the late 14th century by Nchare Yen, a Tikar prince.
history.symbol: Two-headed snake representing dual power and strength

religious_beliefs.traditional: Ancestral worship and local spiritual rites
religious_beliefs.hybrid_religion: Nwet-Nkwete created by Sultan Njoya Ibrahima

festival.name: Nguon
festival.description: Bi-annual festival where the Sultan faces a public trial

culture.museum: Museum of the Bamoun Kings in Foumban

traditional_meals.name: Ekwang
traditional_meals.description: Grated cocoyams wrapped in cocoyam leaves

traditional_meals.name: Ndolé
traditional_meals.description: Stew made with bitter leaves and peanuts

traditional_dress.description: Reserved for royalty and nobles, with symbolic figures sewn onto the fabric

history.origin: Descend from Tikar ancestors who migrated from the northern plateau (around Adamawa) in the 17th century
history.social_structure: Numerous subgroups, each with its own distinct kingdom ruled by a Fon (king)

traditional_meals.name: Nkui
traditional_meals.description: Sticky sauce made from the bark of a tree

traditional_dress.description: Elaborate embroidery with colorful wool threads

history.origin: Trace their origins to migrations from the Congo Basin, likely between the 12th and 14th centuries
history.legend: Ngog Lituba cave myth suggests Egyptian origins

traditional.animism: Belief in spirits inhabiting natural objects

religious_beliefs.modern: Predominantly Christian but with traditional influences

traditional_meals.name: Okok (Ikok/Fumbwa)
traditional_meals.description: Vegetable soup made with eru leaves, palm nuts, and groundnuts

history.origin: Part of the larger Beti-Pahuin ethnic group, migrated from the northern Congo Basin in the 17th or 18th century

traditional.ancestral_spirits: Believed to live among trees, rivers, and skies

culture.folklore: Litéya (folktales filled with wisdom and humor)
culture.architecture: Traditional homes built from mud and raffia

legends.description: Include tales of animal ancestors, forest spirits, and creation myths
legends.example: Sacred crocodile that protects the village waters

history.origin: Subgroup of the Eton, part of the Beti ethnic group, migrated from the northern Congo Basin
history.settlement: Central Region of Cameroon, especially near Obala and Sa'a

traditional.totemism: Certain animals or natural elements considered sacred

religious_beliefs.modern: Predominantly Catholic but with traditional influences

culture.dance: Performed in semi-circles with symbolic gestures

legends.description: Forest mythology including shape-shifting spirits and talking animals
legends.example: Python spirit that helped the Etone cross the forest during migration
